OUTPUT: ['Fortissimo (ff) – very loud', 'Pianississimo (ppp) – very soft', 'Crescendo – gradually getting louder, or increasing in intensity', 'Diminuendo – gradually getting softer or decreasing in intensity', 'Accent – emphasize a note as "very important" within the rhythm', 'Marcato (marked) – notes played with stress and emphasis ("stronger")', 'Sforzando (sfz) – sudden strong accent ("forceful")', 'Forte-piano (fp) – very loud followed by immediate softness', 'Mezzo forte (mf) – moderately loud, but still forceful in presence', 'Subito fortissimo (sffz) – abruptly very loud', 'Ritardando – slowing down ("very gradually") over a period of time', 'Accelerando – speeding up ("gradually faster and more urgent")', 'Tutti – all players performing together, hence "all" or "everyone" can be interpreted as "very many"', 'Fortissimo piano (fp) – very loudly then immediately soft', 'Staccato – short and detached, giving a sense of sharpness ("abrupt") in the music', 'Tenuto – holding or sustaining notes longer than usual, signifying emphasis or importance ', 'Grandioso – grandly, with great force or grandeur ("very majestic")', 'Vibrato – rapid variation in pitch used to enhance musical expression can be seen as "vivid" intensity']
